Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Autologous Osteoblastic Cell Therapy versus Bone Marrow Aspirate Concentrate in Pre-collapse Osteonecrosis of the Femoral Head

Background: This randomised, single-blind trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of autologous osteoblastic cell therapy compared to bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) in patients with pre-collapse osteonecrosis of the femoral head (ONFH).

Methods: Conducted between 2004 and 2011, the study included 67 patients with Stage I or II ONFH, excluding those with traumatic ONFH, hemoglobinopathies, or positive serology for hepatitis B, C, or HIV. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either core decompression with BMAC (n = 26) or osteoblastic cell therapy (n = 30). The primary outcome was the absence of progression to subchondral fracture (ARCO stage III or higher) and a clinically important pain improvement over 36 months. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed. Outcome assessors were blinded.

Results: At 36 months, no significant differences were observed in progression to fracture (46% BMAC vs. 22% osteoblastic cells; hazard ratio, 0.47 [95% CI 0.17 to 1.31]; p = 0.15) or pain scores. No differences were found in THA rates (15% osteoblastic cells vs. 35% BMAC; p = 0.09) or adverse events.

Interpretation: Autologous osteoblastic cell therapy did not demonstrate superiority over BMAC in preventing progression or improving pain in pre-collapse ONFH. Adverse events were uncommon and mild. Further large-scale studies are needed to confirm these findings.

Trial registration: Not provided. Funding: Not reported.
